After the public viewing ended, Cuban Army artillerymen loaded the coffins aboard caissons.<ref name="MaineSinkstoGrave" /> Commander [[Charles Frederick Hughes|Charles F. Hughes]] of the ''Birmingham'' led a contingent of 300 Marines and bluejackets and the ''North Carolina''{{'s}} band escorted the dead to Machina Wharf. Accompanying the funeral cortege were [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[William Herbert Bixby]], Army Corps [[List of United States Army Corps of Engineers Chiefs of Engineers|Chief of Engineers]]; Julio de CÃ¡rdenas, Mayor of Havana; [[Alfredo Zayas y Alfonso]], Vice President of Cuba; and members of the Cuban Cabinet. Six U.S. Navy sailors loaded the first coffins a funeral barge, while Cuban military personnel moved the remainder.<ref name="MaineSinkstoGrave" /> The barges took the remains to the ''North Carolina''. As the ''North Carolina'' passed out of the harbor, soldiers of the Cuban Army lined the walls of La CabaÃ±a and Morro Castle and stood at attention while a military band played a funeral dirge.<ref name="Honorsto" /> Hand-painted [[porcelain]] funeral wreaths, a gift of the Cuban government, were placed on the coffins.<ref name="MaineDeadAwait" />
===Burying the last of the ''Maine'' dead=== [[File:Maines Last Muster - Harpers Weekly - 1912-03-30.jpg|thumb|Coverage of the burial of the last ''Maine'' dead from ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' in 1912.]] The ''USS North Carolina'' arrived at Hampton Roads at about 4:30 P.M. local time on March 19, 1912. Transferral of the dead took until 7:30 P.M. The crews of six other U.S. Navy warships anchored at Hampton Roads stood at attention on their decks, and the ships flew their flags at half-mast. Two battalions of bluejackets from the ''North Carolina'' joined the ''Birmingham'' as an honor guard.<ref>"Maine's Dead Here Today." ''Washington Post.'' March 20, 1912.</ref>
The ''Birmingham'' arrived at the Washington Navy Yard at 10:45 A.M. on March 20. At noon, the coffins were removed from ship and taken to the [[Eisenhower Executive Office Building|State, War, and Navy Building]], one block east of the [[White House]]. A 200-man cavalry unit from Fort Myer carried the coffins aboard caissons. An honor guard consisting of the Third Battalion of the [[3rd Field Artillery Regiment (United States)|Third Field Artillery]];<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /> a battalion of bluejackets from the ''North Carolina''; a battalion of bluejackets from the ''Birmingham''; a battalion of Marines from [[Norfolk, Virginia]]; 200 Army engineers from [[Fort Washington Park|Fort Washington, Maryland]]; a battalion of Marines from Fort Washington; a battalion of bluejackets from the Washington Navy Yard; a battalion of bluejackets from [[Baltimore, Maryland]]; and 50 members of the [[District of Columbia National Guard|District of Columbia Naval National Guard]] accompanied the dead. The naval band from the {{USS|Mayflower|PY-1}} accompanied the honor guard, playing funeral dirges.<ref name="NationHonorsDead">"Nation Honors Dead of Maine." ''Washington Post.'' March 24, 1912.</ref> Tents were erected on the south side of the State, War, and Navy Building, and the caissons bearing the flag-draped coffins lined up beneath the tents at about 2:00 P.M.<ref name="MainesdeadHere" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" />
A brief memorial service was held at 2:30 P.M. Congress adjourned for the ceremony, and the entire [[Cabinet of the United States|Cabinet]] was present. President Taft was the main speaker. On the dais to his right was [[Antonio Martin-Rivero]], [[List of Cuban ambassadors to the United States|Cuban ambassador to the United States]].<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /> To Taft's left were [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] Sigsbee and now-Rear Admiral Wainwright.<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> [[United States Naval Academy]] Chaplain G. Livingston Bayard provided the [[invocation]]. Father Chidwick gave a lengthy oration, followed by a short speech by President Taft. The [[Right Reverend]] W.F. Anderson gave the [[benediction]].<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" />
The funeral cortege then departed for Arlington National Cemetery for a graveside funeral service. President Taft had ordered full military honors for the dead.<ref>"U.S. to Mourn Dead." ''Washington Post.'' March 19, 1912.</ref> The funeral was held near the anchor which constituted the ''Maine'' Memorial,<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> and a tent was set up for President Taft and other dignitaries.<ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> The Marine Corps Band played funeral dirges,<ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> and Chaplain Bayard read the Episcopal funeral service over the dead.<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> Maurice Simmons, Commander of the United Spanish War Veterans, gave a brief speech.<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" /> Eight United Spanish War Veterans served as honorary pall bearers for the dead.<ref name="MaineDeadAwait" /> Three Spanishâ€“American War veterans then laid a white rose, a sprig of evergreen, and a small American flag on the coffins. The Fort Myer cavalry unit delivered a 21-gun salute, followed by a taps played by a bugler. The ceremony ended with a 21-gun salute from cannon at nearby Fort Myer.<ref name="MaineDeadReceive" /><ref name="NationHonorsDead" />
Estimates of the number of dead in the burial field around the monument include 229,<ref>Atkinson, p. 229.</ref> 230,<ref name="OfficialBurials1912" /> and 232.<ref>"Curtain Rung Down on Tragedy That Swept 260 Men to Death on the Ill-Fated Maine." ''Washington Post.'' March 24, 1912.</ref>
==Constructing the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial== [[File:USS Maine Mast.jpg|thumb|upright|The completed Memorial]] As work proceeded on salvaging the wreck of the ''USS Maine'', work on the memorial at Arlington National Cemetery also began. Initially, this work was halted in August 1911 by a lack of funds. The U.S. Army said that the bodies and the ''Maine''{{'s}} mast would be stored at Arlington if no funds were appropriated.<ref>"To Postpone Work on Maine." ''Washington Post.'' August 30, 1911.</ref>
The ''Maine''{{'s}} main mast was brought to the United States by the {{USS|Leonidas|AD-7|6}} in March 1912.<ref name="SoontoFloat" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Bringing Maine's Mast, Naval Collier Leonidas is on the way here|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1912-02-08/ed-1/seq-2/|work=Evening Star (Washington, D.C.)|date=8 February 1912|page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Collier on Way to Annapolis with the Maine Relics|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1912-02-01/ed-1/seq-17/|work=The Washington Times|date=1 February 1912|page=17}}</ref> The ''Maine''{{'s}} foremast was also located, and the {{USS|Sterling|1898|6}} carried it to the U.S. Naval Academy in August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Maine's Mast at Annapolis|work=The Washington Post|date=August 8, 1912|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Maine Foremast at Annapolis|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1912-08-08/ed-1/seq-4/|work=The Evening Star|date=August 8, 1912|page=4|accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Four rejected designs for USS Maine Mast Memorial - Commission of Fine Arts 1915.jpg|thumb|left|Four preliminary designs for the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial which were rejected by the Commission of Fine Arts.]] Work on the memorial began again in early 1912. Just two years earlier, Congress had established the [[United States Commission of Fine Arts]] (CFA), and gave the body the power to advise regarding the siting of monuments and memorials. Given the reputation of the CFA's members (which included some of the most highly regarded architects, painters, landscape architects, sculptors, and other artists of the day) and the strong political support the commission had (particularly from President Taft and the U.S. Senate), the commission's advice was rarely rejected. The CFA reviewed preliminary designs submitted by the War Department, and gave its views on how the memorial should be treated. But no decision was made.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9gYxAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Commission+of+Fine+Arts%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YX2iUf7tBLfe4APt54DABg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAjgo#v=onepage&q&f=false Commission of Fine Arts, ''Report of the Commission of Fine Arts for the Fiscal Year Ending June 30, 1912'', p. 24.] Accessed 2013-05-26.</ref> Privately, the CFA voiced its opinion that the designs submitted were very poor. The commission advised the War Department to select a designer rather than hold a competition. The CFA recommended promising local architect [[Nathan C. Wyeth]], who designed the [[Russell Senate Office Building]] in 1903 and the [[West Wing]] of the [[White House]] in 1909, including the now-iconic [[Oval Office]]. The Secretary of War agreed, and Wyeth was hired to submit a design.<ref name="HABSMaine">[http://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/va1847.sheet.00001a/ ''USS Maine Memorial, Arlington National Cemetery.'' HABS VA,7-ARL,11D- (Sheet 1 of 14). Historic American Buildings Survey. HABS VA-1348-D. 2000.] Accessed 2013-05-26.</ref>
In January 1913, the Corps of Engineers reported that enough funds were left over from salvage of the ''Maine'' to permit construction of the Arlington National Cemetery Memorial.<ref>"Clears Maine Debris." ''Washington Post.'' January 13, 1913.</ref> The following month, shortly before the commemoration ceremonies at the ''Maine'' Memorial at Arlington, President Taft announced his preference for the establishment of the memorial in the field of the ''Maine'' dead rather than another location in the cemetery.<ref>"To Honor Maine Dead." ''Washington Post.'' February 9, 1913.</ref> Secretary of War [[Lindley Miller Garrison]] then placed the design project on hold to allow the CFA to consider placement of the memorial in relation to three other projects also approved for construction: The [[Arlington Memorial Bridge]] (which included a new drive to a new ceremonial gateway to the cemetery), [[Arlington Memorial Amphitheater]], and a receiving vault and chapel.<ref name="WarshipsDepart">"Warships Depart." ''New York Times.'' June 1, 1913.</ref><ref>The Arlington Memorial Bridge Commission and the Memorial Amphitheater were both approved by Congress on March 4, 1913. Unlike the bridge and amphitheater, the chapel at Arlington National Cemetery was never built.</ref> After discussions about the proposed location for the memorial, Wyeth submitted three designs to the CFA. In executive session, the commission made a recommendation to the Secretary of War.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9gYxAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Commission+of+Fine+Arts%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YX2iUf7tBLfe4APt54DABg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAjgo#v=onepage&q&f=false Commission of Fine Arts, ''Report of the Commission of Fine Arts for the Fiscal Year Ending June 30, 1913'', p. 19-20.] Accessed 2013-05-26.</ref> Acting Quartermaster General [[Henry Granville Sharpe]] recommended that Secretary of War Garrison accept Wyeth's design, and he did by June 30, 1913.<ref name="WarshipsDepart" /><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FrlLAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22USS%20Maine%22%20memorial&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false "Report of the Chief of the Quartermaster Corps to the Secretary of War, 1913", p. 11.] Accessed 2013-05-26.</ref>
The cost of the memorial was set at $55,613.<ref name="WarshipsDepart" />
In June 1913, the Washington Navy Yard transferred the ''Maine''{{'s}} mast to Arlington National Cemetery.<ref>"Mast of Battleship Maine Will Soon Mark Graves of Sailors Who Died in Habana." ''Washington Post.'' June 29, 1913.</ref> As the design process proceeded from preliminary to final designs, Wyeth consults extensively with the CFA. In the fall of 1913, the commission approved the placement of a small bronze memorial plaque on the mast itself.<ref name="CFABronzeShield">[https://books.google.com/books?id=9gYxAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Commission+of+Fine+Arts%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YX2iUf7tBLfe4APt54DABg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAjgo#v=onepage&q&f=false Commission of Fine Arts, ''Report of the Commission of Fine Arts for the Fiscal Year Ending June 30, 1914'', p. 32-33.] Accessed 2013-05-26.</ref>
Construction on the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial began in late November 1913. Wyeth's design featured as a base a mausoleum which vaguely looked like a battleship gun turret. The mast of the ''Maine'' pierced the top of this structure, and was set into the floor below. The design called for an exterior made of tan granite, and an interior lined with white marble. The names of those who died aboard the ''Maine'' were to be inscribed on the exterior of the mausoleum. The granite for the structure came from [[Troy, New Hampshire]], and the marble from [[Danby, Vermont]]. Eight months were originally allotted for construction, largely due to the need to chisel the 8,000 letters into the exterior. The Washington, D.C., firm of Norcross Bros. won the $44,637 contract to construct the memorial. This created some controversy, as Norcross was not the lowest bidder. However, Quartermaster General Sharpe recommended Norcross because the company could obtain the stone best suited for the memorial. A month's delay occurred as the contract was contested.<ref>"Work on Maine Memorial." ''Washington Post.'' November 23, 1913.</ref>
In December 1913, the Army Corps of Engineers reported that it had $104,364 in ''Maine'' salvage funds left over.<ref>"Cost $792,989 to Raise the Maine." ''New York Times.'' December 18, 1913.</ref> This included $11,000 to start work on the memorial.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lGFCAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22USS%20Maine%22%201910&pg=PR6#v=onepage&q&f=false Special Board of Engineer Officers, p. 6.] Accessed 2013-05-17.</ref>
Initial work on the memorial proceeded quickly. Memorial services of the ''Maine'' dead were held at the unfinished memorial on February 15, 1914.<ref>"Flags and Flowers for Graves of Maine Heroes." ''Washington Post.'' February 15, 1914.</ref> For the first time, a joint ceremony sponsored by the [[Grand Army of the Republic]], [[Army and Navy Union of the United States of America|Army and Navy Union]], and United Spanish War Veterans was held to pay tribute to the ''Maine''.<ref name="Maine Dead 1914">"Honor to Maine Dead." ''Washington Post.'' February 15, 1914.</ref> The United Spanish War Veterans women's auxiliary laid a wreath on the memorial's anchor, and Cuban ambassador [[Carlos Manuel de CÃ©spedes]] laid a wreath at the unfinished memorial.<ref name="Maine Dead 1914"/>
Problems in obtaining stone and cost overruns greatly delayed construction of the memorial. By August 1914, the cost of the structure had risen to $60,000.<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion">"Honor Maine Victims." ''Washington Post.'' August 9, 1914.</ref> Most of the stone for the exterior and interior did not arrive until mid September, and the stonecutters needed six more weeks to ensure the stone was ready for placement.<ref>"Stone for Maine Memorial." ''Washington Post.'' September 13, 1914.</ref> By mid October, the mast had been set and most of the exterior was in place.<ref>"Edifice Near Graves." ''Washington Post.'' October 18, 1914.</ref> Even so, the memorial's completion was not expected until November 1, 1915.<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" />
The contractor worked swiftly to try to complete the memorial faster. On January 30, Army officials said the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial would probably be dedicated on Memorial Day.<ref>"Services for Maine Dead." ''Washington Post.'' January 31, 1915.</ref> On February 15, President [[Woodrow Wilson]] and [[Mario GarcÃ­a Menocal]], President of Cuba, both placed large floral wreaths at the unfinished memorial.<ref>"Maine Memorial Services." ''Washington Post.'' February 15, 1915.</ref> Charles H. Tompkins, Inc., of Washington, D.C., did the grading at the site.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JSdYAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Maine%20memorial%22%20Arlington%20repair&pg=RA7-PA36#v=onepage&q&f=false "Street Improvements." ''The American Contractor.'' February 20, 1915, p. 36.] Accessed 2013-05-27.</ref>
===Dedication of the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial=== [[File:Dedication of USS Maine Mast Memorial - Arlington National Cemetery - 1915-02-15.jpg|thumb|Dedication of the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial by President Woodrow Wilson on Memorial Day in 1915.]] Dedication of the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial occurred on May 30, 1915, as part of larger Memorial Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery. At noon, President Wilson led a march of dignitaries and veterans from the White House to the [[Civil War Unknowns Monument]], where he laid a wreath. Wilson and the dignitaries then proceeded to the [[Old Amphitheater]], where he and others delivered speeches.<ref name="ForHeroDead">"Honors For Hero Dead." ''Washington Post.'' May 16, 1915.</ref>
At 3:00 P.M., a regiment of U.S. Marines escorted President Wilson to the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial.<ref name="HonorToday">"Honor Heroes Today." ''Washington Post.'' May 31, 1915.</ref><ref name="WilsonAt">"Wilson at Arlington." ''Washington Post.'' June 1, 1915.</ref><ref name="Cheered">"Cheered At Arlington." ''New York Times.'' June 1, 1915.</ref> The ceremony began with an invocation by Father Chidwick.<ref name="ForHeroDead" /> Secretary of the Navy [[Josephus Daniels]] spoke first, followed by Charles Cramer, Commander of United Spanish War Veterans, and H. Oden Lake, National Commander of the Army and Navy Union.<ref name="ForHeroDead" /><ref name="Cheered" />
Following the speeches, the American flag was raised to the top of the mast by Frank Arthur Daniels (age 11) and [[Jonathan W. Daniels|Jonathon Worth Daniels]] (age 13), sons of Secretary of the Navy Josephus Daniels. The Daniels boys were nephews of [[Ensign (rank)#United States|Ensign]] [[Worth Bagley]], the first and only American naval officer to die in the Spanishâ€“American War.<ref name="WilsonAt" /><ref name="Cheered" /> The Daniels boys also raised [[International maritime signal flags|signal flags]] which spelled out "Maine 1915". A 21-gun salute from cannon at Fort Myer occurred as the flags were raised.<ref name="WilsonAt" /> After the flag and signals were up, 50 Marines in [[Uniforms of the United States Navy|dress whites]] climbed into the rigging supporting the mast.<ref name="WilsonAt" /><ref name="Cheered" /> The flag-raising was followed by speeches by [[John McElroy]], Commander of the Department of the Potomac chapter of the Grand Army of the Republic; Major Robert Lee Longstreet, son of [[American Civil War]] [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#Lieutenant general|Lieutenant General]] [[James Longstreet]] of the [[Confederate States Army]]; and Dr. [[Carlos Manuel de CÃ©spedes y Quesada]], Cuban ambassador to the United States.<ref name="WilsonAt" /><ref name="Cheered" /> Taps were played to end the ceremony. Marines fired a 21-gun salute to President Wilson as the ceremonies ended.<ref name="WilsonAt" /><ref name="Cheered" />
After the official dedication ended, several veterans groups held a joint ceremony at the new ''Maine'' Mast Memorial.<ref name="HonorToday" /> Rear Admiral [[George Washington Baird]] (ret.) spoke about the history of the battleship, the ''USS Maine'', and the ship's salvaging.<ref name="WilsonAt" /> [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[William Jennings Bryan]] spoke afterward.<ref name="Cheered" />
On August 14, 1915, Secretary of War Garrison said that the [[Antiquities Act|Antiquities Act of 1906]] encompassed the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial. This required the federal government to care for the monument in perpetuity.<ref>"To Care For Monuments." ''Washington Post.'' August 15, 1915.</ref>
==About the memorial== [[File:USS Maine bell on entrance door - USS Maine Mast Memorial - Arlington National Cemetery - 2013-03-15.jpg|thumb|Bell of the ''USS Maine'', broken in half by the 1898 explosion, attached to the door of the memorial at Arlington National Cemetery.]] The ''Maine'' Mast Memorial is located on Sigsbee Drive in Arlington National Cemetery.<ref>Holt. p. 337.</ref> The monument is due west of [[Arlington Memorial Amphitheater]].<ref>Lemos, et al., p. 250-251.</ref>
The memorial consists of the main mast of the ''USS Maine'' set upright into the center of a circular, stylized mausoleum shaped to look like a battleship gun turret.<ref name="HABSMaine" /><ref name="WilsonAt" /><ref name="Cheered" /> The structure is {{convert|90|ft|m}} in diameter and {{convert|15|ft|m}} high.<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" /> The mast pierces the roof the memorial, and is sunk into the floor inside.<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" /> The mausoleum is constructed of [[reinforced concrete]], sheathed in tan granite on the outside and white marble on the interior.<ref name="HABSMaine" /> The names and ranks of those who died aboard the ''Maine'' are carved into the exterior of the mausoleum,<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" /> organized into 23 panels.<ref name="HABSMaine" /> There are eleven slit windows with bronze grills in the structure. The interior roof is a shallow dome, and the interior floor is lined with mosaic tile.<ref name="HABSMaine" /> The single entry to the mausoleum has two doors. The inner door is made of wood, and half the ship's bell (retrieved from the ocean floor in 1911) is attached to the outer side of this door.<ref name="HABSMaine" /><ref name="AshesLothian">"Ashes of Lord Lothian Rest in Arlington." ''New York Times.'' December 17, 1940.</ref> The outer door is a bronze gate decorated with metal rope and anchors.<ref name="HABSMaine" /> Ceremonial stone funeral urns stand on either side of the entryway.<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" /> Above the door is carved the following: "Erected in memory of the officers and men who lost their lives in the destruction of the U.S.S. Maine, Habana, Cuba, February 15, 1898".<ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" />
A road encircles the memorial. On the east side of the memorial is a concrete pad on which the anchor manufactured in 1900 sits.<ref name="Pepper343" /><ref name="HABSMaine" /><ref>At least two of the ''Maine''{{'s}} anchors are accounted for. One anchor was given to the United Spanish War Veterans, who melted it down and made insignia for its members. See: Piehler, p. 90-91. The other anchor is in City Park in [[Reading, Pennsylvania]]. Representative [[John Hoover Rothermel|John H. Rothermel]] used political connections to obtain the anchor from the Washington Navy Yard, which had possession of it. The anchor was dedicated on August 1, 1914, by then-Assistant Secretary of the Navy [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] in front of a crowd of about 13,000 people. See: Blow, p. 447; [http://readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=101544 Cuyler, Greta. "Group Recalls Dedication of Anchor from U.S. Warship in Reading's City Park." ''Reading Eagle.'' August 11, 2008], accessed 2013-05-22.</ref> Two bronze Spanish mortars, cast in the 1700s and captured by Admiral Dewey during the Spanishâ€“American War at Cavite Arsenal in the Philippines, flank the anchor.<ref name="HABSMaine" /> Originally, these mortars were placed atop brick piers with concrete caps. But when the anchor and mortars were incorporated into the new memorial, two granite [[balustrade]]s were added along the roadway near the mortars.<ref name="HABSMaine" /><ref name="HonorVictimsCompletion" />
A bronze shield was affixed to the mast by the Havana chapter of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]] while it was still in Havana.<ref name="WilsonAt" /> This shield was retained when the mast was erected in 1915.<ref name="CFABronzeShield" />
The memorial's 100th anniversary was celebrated on May 30, 2015. Dave Kammen, Director of Events and Ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery, presided over a wreath-laying ceremony at the memorial. A U.S. Navy honor guard assisted in observing the event, at which "[[Taps]]" was played.
===Changes to the memorial=== In 1962, a [[Terrace (building)|terrace]] was constructed for the anchor and mortars. The terrace is paved with [[Bluestone#In the United States and Canada|bluestone]] flagstones, and bluestone also replaced the concrete pad on which the anchor rested.<ref name="HABSMaine" />
Minor repairs were made to the memorial in 1917 and 1995.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6ylJAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22Maine%20memorial%22%20Arlington%20repair&pg=PA1825#v=onepage&q&f=false "Report of the Chief of Engineers, U.S. Army, 1917", p. 1825], accessed 2013-05-27; National Capital Planning Commission, p. 121.</ref> The memorial underwent a $500,000 partial restoration in 2010.<ref>Subcommittee of the Committee on Appropriations, p. 189.</ref>
In 2013, the ''USS Maine'' Mast Memorial began undergoing a complete restoration. The two-phase project began in September 2012 and is anticipated to be complete by Memorial Day in 2014. The first phase of the project will document the memorial's construction history, physical characteristics, and areas in need of renovation. Conservation recommendations will be part of this phase. The second phase of the project will involve conserving, restoring, and renovating the mast, the mast rigging, the terrace, and the approaches to the memorial. The goal of the second phase will be to restore to the memorial as much as possible to its original condition. This includes restoring damage, replacing lost pieces or parts, and eliminating alterations.<ref>[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/News/NewsItem.aspx?ID=6613c314-0b46-44f9-86c5-2c8156ebe886 Bohan, Melissa. "Restoration Ongoing for Mast of the Maine; Upcoming for JFK Flame." Public Affairs Office. Arlington National Cemetery. January 28, 2013.] Accessed 2013-06-25.</ref>
==Temporary entombments at the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial== [[File:100th Anniversary of the USS Maine Memorial Dedication.webm|thumb|100th anniversary of the USS Maine Mast Memorial dedication in 2015.]] Constructed as a mausoleum, the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial has served as the resting place for several individuals.
[[File:Burial of Ignacy Jan Paderewski - Maine Mast Memorial - Arlington National Cemetery US - 1941.jpg|thumb|right|Burial of Ignacy Jan Paderewski at the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial in 1941.]]
===Lord Lothian=== Beginning in 1939, [[Philip Kerr, 11th Marquess of Lothian]] was [[List of Ambassadors of the United Kingdom to the United States|British ambassador to the United States]]. Lord Lothian died unexpectedly in December 1940. His remains were cremated, but with the [[Battle of the Atlantic]] making sea travel risky and air travel limited to only items of the highest importance, the [[United Kingdom]] agreed that Lord Lothian's ashes should remain in the United States until such time as they might be safely conveyed across the Atlantic. His ashes were interred in the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial on December 15, 1940, after a funeral at the [[Washington National Cathedral]].<ref name="AshesLothian" /><ref>Hinton, Harold B. "Ashes of Lothian Going to Arlington." ''New York Times.'' December 14, 1940.</ref>
Lord Lothian's ashes were returned to the United Kingdom aboard an American naval vessel in December 1945.<ref>Olson, p. 272.</ref>
===Ignacy Jan Paderewski=== In 1940, the internationally known pianist and composer [[Ignacy Jan Paderewski]] was named head of the [[Polish National Council]], a Polish [[Sejm|parliament]] in exile in [[London]]. He traveled extensively in the United States, building public support for the Polish people (who were under [[Nazi Germany|Nazi German]] rule). Paderewski fell ill on June 27, 1941, while on a speaking tour in America. The 80-year-old diplomat was diagnosed with [[pneumonia]], and died in [[New York City]] on June 29. His body was temporarily interred in the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial on July 5, 1941, with the stipulation of the Polish National Council that they would be returned only to a free Poland.<ref>"Paderewski Rests With Heroes of U.S." ''United Press International.'' July 6, 1941.</ref> President [[John F. Kennedy]] dedicated a plaque on the interior of the memorial in May 1963, honoring Paderewski's memory.<ref name="PaderHome">[http://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/25/arts/paderewski-to-go-home-51-years-after-his-death.html Kozinn, Allan. "Paderewski to Go Home, 51 Years After His Death." ''New York Times.'' June 25, 1992.] Accessed 2013-05-22.</ref>
Paderewski's remains were taken back to Poland in July 1992, 51 years after his death and two years after the [[History of Poland (1945â€“89)#Facing the inevitable|collapse of the Polish communist dictatorship]].<ref name="PaderHome" />
===Manuel Quezon=== [[Manuel Quezon]] was elected [[President of the Philippines]] for a second term on November 11, 1941. Just 27 days later, the [[Empire of Japan]] invaded the [[Philippines]] in what became known as the [[Philippines Campaign (1941â€“1942)|Philippines Campaign]]. On March 27, 1942, Quezon and his government fled the Philippines as the final American and Filipino defensive lines neared collapse.<ref>"Quezon Joins MacArthur in Australia With Staff." ''Associated Press.'' March 27, 1942.</ref> He traveled to the United States on May 9, 1942, and established a [[government in exile]] there.<ref>Davies, Lawrence E. "Quezon Arrives at San Francisco." ''New York Times.'' May 9, 1942.</ref> Quezon was extremely ill with [[tuberculosis]], however, and he died at a [[Cure Cottages of Saranac Lake|"cure cottage"]] in [[Saranac Lake, New York]], on August 1, 1944. His body was placed in the ''Maine'' Mast Memorial until it could be returned to a liberated Philippines.<ref>Gurney and Wise, p. 78; Goettel, p. 207; Pabico, p. 112.</ref>
Quezon's body was flown back to the Philippines on June 29, 1946.<ref>"Quezon's Body Starts for Manila Tuesday." ''New York Times.'' June 29, 1946.</ref>
